facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2416 and 2417 of 1966 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2416 and 2417 of 1966. Appeals from the judgment and order dated March

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1963 of the Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 281 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1963 of the Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 281 of 1960.

facts.text: The property in dispute is a building in Jullundur City in which there is located a cinema formerly called Chitra Talkies and now known as Odeon Cinema.

anchor.surface_text: The property in dispute is a building in Jullundur City in which there is located a cinema. It was formerly called Chitra Talkies and number is known as Odeon Cinema.

facts.text: The building was constructed in 1933 on land measuring 3 kanals and 17 marlas.

anchor.surface_text: The building was companystructed in 1933 on land measuring 3 kanals and 17 marlas. The original owner-one Azim Baksh--migrated to Pakistan in 1947

facts.text: Original owner Azim Baksh migrated to Pakistan in 1947 and the property was declared evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The original owner-one Azim Baksh--migrated to Pakistan in 1947 and this property was declared evacuee property.

facts.text: On January 21, 1946 Azim Baksh mortgaged the building with possession for Rs. 70,000/- with Malawa Ram and Gamda Mal.

anchor.surface_text: Before migration Azim Baksh had dealt with this property in several ways. On January 21, 1946 he had mortgaged the building with possession for Rs. 70,000/- with Malawa Ram and Gamda Mal.

facts.text: On January 22, 1946 Azim Baksh took the building on lease on a rent of Rs. 162.8 annas for 11 months from the mortgagees and executed a rent note.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1946 Azim Baksh took the building on leaseon a rent of Rs. 162.8 annas for 11 months from the mortgagees. He executed a rent numbere.

facts.text: On February 8, 1946 the rent note was cancelled with endorsement by consent of Lal Gainda Ram and Malawa Ram allowing mortgagees to carry on cinema or lease to others.

anchor.surface_text: On February 8, 1946 this rent numbere was cancelled. An endorsement was made on the rent numbere to the following effect With the companysent of Lal Gainda Ram and Malawa Ram, the said rent-deed has been cancelled.

facts.text: Previously Azim Baksh had rented this building to Sant Ram and Sita Ram on Rs. 150/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: Previously Azim Baksh had rented this building to Sant Ram and Sita Ram on Rs. 150/- per month.

facts.text: After the release of the property the mortgagees leased it to Sita Ram and Sohan Lal on Rs. 200/- per month, terminated on July 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: After the release of the property the mortgagees leased it to Sita Ram and Sohan Lal on Rs. 200/- per month. This lease was terminated on July 26, 1950.

facts.text: In August 1951 the mortgagees leased it to All India Film Corporation Ltd. (appellant No. 1, defendant No. 2) on Rs. 250/- per month for 5 years from September 15, 1951 to September 14, 1956, renewable for 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: On August, 1951 the mortgagees leased it to the All India Film Corporation Ltd., appellant No. 1  defendant No. 2 , on Rs. 250/- per month vide Ex. D.2 W.2/1. The lease was for 5 years in the first instance from September 15, 1951 to September 14, 1956.

facts.text: The lease to All India Film Corporation gave full right to use the property by itself, agents, partnership or sub-leasing.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, renewable for 10 years by yearly renewals. There was a companydition that renewal on the same terms was number to be refused. By this lease, the lessee was given full right to use the property whether by itself or through agents or in partnership or by sub-leasing.

facts.text: Malawa Ram and Gainda Mal partitioned their property and this house fell to the share of Gainda Mal.

anchor.surface_text: Malawa Ram and Gainda Mal partitioned their property and this house fell to the share of Gainda Mal.

facts.text: All India Film Corporation sub-let the premises to defendants 3 to 9 on May 16, 1952 on monthly rent of Rs. 1,250/- including machinery.

anchor.surface_text: The lessee companypany in its turn sub-let the premises to defendants 3 to 9 on a monthly rent of Rs. 1,250/-. This was on May 16, 1952.

facts.text: Before subleasing, All India Film Corporation equipped the house with cinema machinery etc.

anchor.surface_text: Before subleasing the premises, the head lessee companypany had equipped the house with cinema machinery etc. and the sub-lease included the use of machinery etc.

facts.text: Gainda Mal applied under Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 for separation of his interest.

anchor.surface_text: Gainda Mal applied under Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 for separation of his interest.

facts.text: Competent Officer by order dated August 25, 1955 determined mortgage charge as Rs. 90,807.4 annas and ordered sale of the building and land together with another plot.

anchor.surface_text: The Competent Officer by his order, August 25, 1955, determined the mortgage charge as Rs. 90,807.4 annas and ordered sale of the building and land together with another plot.

facts.text: Raja Gyan Nath purchased the cinema with land 3 kanals 17 marlas for Rs. 65,000/- on December 3, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in this appeal Raja Gyan Nath purchased the cinema with the land  3 kanals 17 marlas  for Rs. 65,000/- on December 3, 1955.

facts.text: Sale certificate was issued on March 3, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The sale certificate was issued on March 3, 1956.

facts.text: The mortgage charge was paid off on April 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage charge was paid off on April 19, 1958.

facts.text: Raja Gyan Nath filed suit for possession from head lessee and sub-lessees on August 5, 1959 and for mesne profits at Rs. 1,250/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: The purchaser Raja Gyan Nath then filed a suit for possession of this property from the head lessee and the sub-lessees on August 5, 1959 and for mesne profits at the rate of Rs. 1,250/- per month.

facts.text: Sub-lessees claimed benefit of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act 3 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The sub-lessees claimed the benefit of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act  3 of 1949 .

facts.text: Plaintiff gave up claim to cinema machinery, furniture and fittings.

anchor.surface_text: Later the plaintiff gave up his claim to the cinema machinery, furniture and fittings.

facts.text: Trial Judge decreed possession and mesne profits at Rs. 500/- per month, disallowed half costs.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge decreed the claim in full except that mesne profits were reduced to Rs. 500/- per month and half of the companyts were disallowed.

facts.text: Defendants 2, 4, 10 and 11 appealed to High Court; plaintiff cross-objected for Rs. 1,250/- mesne profits with 6% interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 2, 4, 10 and 11 appealed against the decree to the High Court. The plaintiff cross-objected asking for mesne profits at Rs. 1,250/- with interest at 6 per year and the remaining companyts.

facts.text: High Court affirmed decree but reduced mesne profits to Rs. 250/- per month from date of suit till possession with 6% interest.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court affirmed the decree, but reduced mesne profits further from Rs. 500/- to Rs. 250/- per month. The mesne profits were to run from the date of suit till possession with interest at 6 per annum.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate to both sides for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court granted a certificate to both sides and they have filed their respective appeals.

facts.text: Head lessee invested Rs. 60,000/- equipping the building.

anchor.surface_text: The history of the building in the hands of the head lessee shows that after an investment of Rs. 60,000/- the rent went upto Rs. 1,250 p.m.

facts.text: Annual rent of the building was assessed at Rs. 10,800/- for 1950-55.

anchor.surface_text: The learned subordinate Judge pointed out that the annual rent of the building was assessed at Rs. 10,800/- for the years 1950--55.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that tenancy created by mortgagee did not survive termination of mortgagee's interest.

anchor.surface_text: Did the tenancy created by the mortgagee in possession survive the termination of the mortgagee interest so as to be binding on the purchaser ? ... Therefore on redemption of the mortgage the title of the mortgagee companyes to an end.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sub-lessees not protected by East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act as no tenancy survived.

anchor.surface_text: It is whether the tenants companyld take advantage of the provisions of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 ? The answer to this question deFends on whether we can say that there was a tenancy to protect.

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed mesne profits at Rs. 250/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reduced the mesne profits to Rs. 250/- p.m. which was the actual rent paid for the building and the passage. ... The High Court was, therefore, number wrong in limiting mesne profits to that figure.

Gainda Mal applied under Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 for separation of his interest. The Competent Officer by his order, August 25, 1955, determined the mortgage charge as Rs. 90,807.4 annas and ordered sale of the building and land together with another plot.

anchor.surface_text: The first question to consider is this Did the tenancy created by the mortgagee in possession survive the termination of the mortgagee interest so as to be binding on the purchaser ? A general proposition of law is that no person can confer on another a better title than he himself has. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in specific immovable property for the purpose of securing repayment of a loan.

holdings.text: The tenants could not take advantage of the provisions of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949

anchor.surface_text: It is whether the tenants could take advantage of the provisions of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 ? The answer to this question depends on whether we can say that there was a tenancy to protect. We have shown above that the lease came to an end with the mortgagees interest in the property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No surviving tenancy or landlord-tenant relationship after mortgage termination, rent act definitions presuppose tenancy

holdings.text: There being no landlord and no tenant, the provisions of the Rent Restriction Act could not apply any further

anchor.surface_text: There being no landlord and no tenant, the provisions of the Rent Restriction Act could not apply any further. Nor could it be said that when the mortgagor cancelled the rent note and authorised the mortgagee to find any other tenant, the intention was to allow expressly a tenancy beyond the term of the mortgage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extinction of mortgagee's interest under Evacuee Act s.10 sale ends all derivative tenancies

holdings.text: The High Court was, therefore, not wrong in limiting mesne profits to Rs. 250/- p.m.

anchor.surface_text: There remains to consider the question of mesne profits. The High Court reduced the mesne profits to Rs. 250/- p.m. which was the actual rent paid for the building and the passage. There is some doubt as to whether this sum included Rs. 100/- for the use of the passage. However, we think that the matter is between the purchaser and the head lessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mesne profits measured by actual rent paid by head lessee to mortgagee

holdings.text: The scheme of s. 10 of the Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 led to extinction of the mortgagees interest and full title to the purchaser

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of s. 10 of the Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 is that in the case of a mortgagor or a mortgagee, the Competent Officer may pay to the Custodian or the claimant the amount payable under the mortgage debt and redeem the property, or b the Competent Officer may sell the mortgaged property for satisfaction of the mortgage debt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale under method (c) satisfied debt, united interests in purchaser

anchor.surface_text: The first question to consider is this Did the tenancy created by the mortgagee in possession survive the termination of the mortgagee interest so as to be binding on the purchaser ? A general proposition of law is that no person can confer on another a better title than he himself has. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in specific immovable property for the purpose of securing repayment of a loan.

anchor.surface_text: There being no landlord and no tenant, the provisions of the Rent Restriction Act could not apply any further. Nor could it be said that when the mortgagor cancelled the rent note and authorised the mortgagee to find any other tenant, the intention was to allow expressly a tenancy beyond the term of the mortgage.

There being no landlord and no tenant, the provisions of the Rent Restriction Act could not apply any further. Nor could it be said that when the mortgagor cancelled the rent note and authorised the mortgagee to find any other tenant, the intention was to allow expressly a tenancy beyond the term of the mortgage.

There remains to consider the question of mesne profits. The High Court reduced the mesne profits to Rs. 250/- p.m. which was the actual rent paid for the building and the passage. There is some doubt as to whether this sum included Rs. 100/- for the use of the passage. However, we think that the matter is between the purchaser and the head lessee.

anchor.surface_text: There remains to consider the question of mesne profits. The High Court reduced the mesne profits to Rs. 250/- p.m. which was the actual rent paid for the building and the passage. There is some doubt as to whether this sum included Rs. 100/- for the use of the passage. However, we think that the matter is between the purchaser and the head lessee.

The scheme of s. 10 of the Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 is that in the case of a mortgagor or a mortgagee, the Competent Officer may pay to the Custodian or the claimant the amount payable under the mortgage debt and redeem the property, or b the Competent Officer may sell the mortgaged property for satisfaction of the mortgage debt
